item.title: Sample Page
item.dc:creator: kp5gs
item.content:encoded:
This is an example page. It's different from a blog post because it will stay in one place and will show up in your site navigation (in most themes). Most people start with an About page that introduces them to potential site visitors. It might say something like this:

Hi there! I'm a bike messenger by day, aspiring actor by night, and this is my website. I live in Los Angeles, have a great dog named Jack, and I like piña coladas. (And gettin' caught in the rain.)

...or something like this:

The XYZ Doohickey Company was founded in 1971, and has been providing quality doohickeys to the public ever since. Located in Gotham City, XYZ employs over 2,000 people and does all kinds of awesome things for the Gotham community.

As a new WordPress user, you should go to your dashboard to delete this page and create new pages for your content. Have fun!

[Wow-Login login="google"]

item.title: Privacy Policy
item.dc:creator: kp5gs
item.content:encoded:
Who we are

Our website address is: https://recipes.ihathaway.com.

What personal data we collect and why we collect it

Comments

When visitors leave comments on the site we collect the data shown in the comments form, and also the visitor’s IP address and browser user agent string to help spam detection.

An anonymized string created from your email address (also called a hash) may be provided to the Gravatar service to see if you are using it. The Gravatar service privacy policy is available here: https://automattic.com/privacy/. After approval of your comment, your profile picture is visible to the public in the context of your comment.

Media

If you upload images to the website, you should avoid uploading images with embedded location data (EXIF GPS) included. Visitors to the website can download and extract any location data from images on the website.

Contact forms

Cookies

If you leave a comment on our site you may opt-in to saving your name, email address and website in cookies. These are for your convenience so that you do not have to fill in your details again when you leave another comment. These cookies will last for one year.

If you visit our login page, we will set a temporary cookie to determine if your browser accepts cookies. This cookie contains no personal data and is discarded when you close your browser.

When you log in, we will also set up several cookies to save your login information and your screen display choices. Login cookies last for two days, and screen options cookies last for a year. If you select "Remember Me", your login will persist for two weeks. If you log out of your account, the login cookies will be removed.

If you edit or publish an article, an additional cookie will be saved in your browser. This cookie includes no personal data and simply indicates the post ID of the article you just edited. It expires after 1 day.

Embedded content from other websites

Articles on this site may include embedded content (e.g. videos, images, articles, etc.). Embedded content from other websites behaves in the exact same way as if the visitor has visited the other website.

These websites may collect data about you, use cookies, embed additional third-party tracking, and monitor your interaction with that embedded content, including tracking your interaction with the embedded content if you have an account and are logged in to that website.

Analytics

Who we share your data with

How long we retain your data

If you leave a comment, the comment and its metadata are retained indefinitely. This is so we can recognize and approve any follow-up comments automatically instead of holding them in a moderation queue.

For users that register on our website (if any), we also store the personal information they provide in their user profile. All users can see, edit, or delete their personal information at any time (except they cannot change their username). Website administrators can also see and edit that information.

What rights you have over your data

If you have an account on this site, or have left comments, you can request to receive an exported file of the personal data we hold about you, including any data you have provided to us. You can also request that we erase any personal data we hold about you. This does not include any data we are obliged to keep for administrative, legal, or security purposes.

Where we send your data

Visitor comments may be checked through an automated spam detection service.

Your contact information

Additional information

How we protect your data

What data breach procedures we have in place

What third parties we receive data from

What automated decision making and/or profiling we do with user data

Industry regulatory disclosure requirements

item.title: McCall's Old-Fashioned Apple Pie
item.dc:creator: ohathawa
item.content:encoded:
An American Tradition As Old As... So, Bella made this for Thanksgiving 2019. She got real frustrated with the pie crust because she kept working it until it warmed up and became real gooey. As we all know, pie pastry must be kept cool to work it right. That way it turns out nice and buttery.

McCall's Old-Fashioned Apple Pie

So, this recipe is really old. Almost as old as Michelle is ;)

  • 2 pastry pie crust dough
  • 1 cup sugar
  • 1 tsp cinnamon
  • 4 tbsp flour
  • 1 dash salt
  • 6 cups thinly sliced, pared tart cooking apples (2 lbs)
  • 2 tbsp butter

  1. On lightly floured surface, roll out half of pastry into an 11-inch circle. Use to line 9-inch pie plate; trim. Refrigerate, with rest of pastry until ready to use.

  2. Preheat oven to 425F

  3. In small bowl, combine sugar, cinnamon, flour, and salt, mixing well.

  4. Add to apples in large bowl, tossing lightly to combine.

  5. Turn into pastry-lined pie plate, mounding high in center; dot with butter.

  6. Roll out remaining pastry into an 11-inch circle. Make several slits near center for steam vents; adjust over filling; trim.

  7. Fold edge of top crust under bottom crust; press together with fingertips. Crimp edge decoratively.

  8. Bake 45 to 50 minutes, or until apples are tender and crust is golden-brown.

  9. Cool partially on wire rack; serve warm.

item.title: McCall's Old-Fashioned Apple Pie
item.dc:creator: kp5gs
item.content:encoded:
So, this recipe is really old. Almost as old as Michelle is ;) Here, we can write little articles about our food that help make it 'homey.'

McCall's Old-Fashioned Apple Pie

An American Tradition As Old As...

  • 2 pie pastry crust
  • 1 cup sugar
  • 1 tsp cinnamon
  • 4 tbsp flour
  • 1 dash salt
  • 6 cups thinly sliced, pared tart cooking apples (2 lbs)
  • 2 tbsp butter or margarine

  1. On lightly floured surface, roll out half of pastry into an 11-inch circle. Use to line 9-inch pie plate; trim. Refrigerate, with rest of pastry, until ready to use.

  2. Preheat oven to 425F.

  3. In small bowl, combine sugar, cinnamon, flour, and salt, mixing well.

  4. Add to apples in large bowl, tossing lightly to combine.

  5. Turn into pastry-lined pie plate, mounding high in center; dot with butter.

  6. Roll out remaining pastry into an 11-inch circle. Make several slits near center for steam vents; adjust over filling; trim.

  7. Fold edge of top crust under bottom crust; press together with fingertips. Crimp edge decoratively.

  8. Bake 45 to 50 minutes, or until apples are tender and crust is golden-brown.

  9. Cool partially on wire rack; serve warm.

Bella made this for Thanksgiving 2019.

She got real frustrated with making the pastry because it kept getting too warm. When that happens with pastry dough, it gets flimsy and difficult to work with.

item.title: Smoked Thanksgiving Turkey
item.dc:creator: ohathawa
item.content:encoded:
Michelle doesn't like turkey very much. She's not super picky about food, so she'll eat it. She just doesn't think it tastes like much and isn't worth the time and effort. This recipe, she likes. We've been cooking our Thanksgiving turkeys this way for so long that I forget where I learned this method. I know I used to do this before I moved out of my parents home, so that means it's been over 20 years of turkeys this way. This turkey comes out smelling awesome. The taste is a little tangy, a little piney, and a lot smokey. While your holiday table will smell wonderful. The flavors become more pronounced after refrigerating for a day. Those leftover turkey sandwiches for Friday... they'll be amazing. You can't cook this in an oven, so you'll need either a charcoal grill or a smoker to do this. Also, I absolutely insist on using an instant-read meat thermometer. I don't like the leave-it-in style, and temperature is the only way to know when meat is safe to eat. (That is, unless you cook it for 20 hours at 200F like we do the brisket, but that's another story)

Smoked Thanksgiving Turkey

Using this method of cooking a turkey is the perfect way to ensure an ill-timed meal on Thanksgiving. Even so, it's the only method I'm allowed to use at our house.

  • 1 turkey ( any size will do, try not to get one that's been brined as this will change the flavor a little)
  • 5 limes
  • 4 sprigs fresh rosemary

  1. Make sure the turkey is defrosted before you start. This absolutely won't work with a partially frozen turkey. Estimate 30 minutes in the fridge for every pound of turkey (e.g. 8 hours for a 16 lb bird).

  2. If you're using a Weber kettle, set it up for indirect heat. For this recipe, I build two piles of 20 briquettes each on either side of the grill. Douse the piles with lighter fluid and light 'em up. Let those coals cook while you prep the bird.

  3. Unpackage the bird and rinse it off. Try to remove any left-over feathers and such. Put the neck and giblets in a bowl and set aside.

  4. Using a very sharp chef's knife, cut the bird in half along the breast bone. Turn it over and do the same along the spine. I like to remove the spine, but this method works just fine if you don't. If you do remove the spine, cut into 2 or 3 pieces and put it in the bowl with the neck.

    Be careful not to cut into either the breast bone or the spine as your knife will stick and you'll end up frustrated. It does take some force to get through the ribs, so put a little weight into it, and be very aware of where your fingers are.

  5. Trim off any loose flaps of skin around the neck and tail areas. Place those in the bowl with the neck.

  6. Cover the neck bowl with plastic wrap and refrigerate.

  7. Set the turkey halves bone-side down in the sink. Cut the limes into wedges, and squeeze them over the turkey halves. Make sure you get juice over the entire skin, including under the legs and wings. Tuck a few wedges under the wings and legs.

  8. Remove the rosemary leaves from the sprigs and cover the turkey halves with them. If you have enough over, place a small sprig under each wing

  9. If you're using a gas or electric smoker, set it up for smoking at around 180 - 220F. Lower will be longer and smokier. Just make sure it's over 160F though or the bird will never cook to a safe temperature.

    I put a metal bowl of water in the cooking chamber, but I only just started doing this. I think it does result in juicier meat.

  10. If you're using a Webber kettle, you'll need to add 5 briquettes to each pile before you put the bird on.

    Repeat this every 45 minutes or so while the bird cooks.

  11. Put the bird on the grill/smoker and cook to an internal temperature of 160F.

Michelle doesn't like turkey very much. She's not super picky about food, so she'll eat it. She just doesn't think it tastes like much and isn't worth the time and effort. This recipe, she likes.<\/p>

We've been cooking our Thanksgiving turkeys this way for so long that I forget where I learned this method. I know I used to do this before I moved out of my parents home, so that means it's been over 20 years of turkeys this way.<\/p>

This turkey comes out smelling awesome. The taste is a little tangy, a little piney, and a lot smokey. While your holiday table will smell wonderful. The flavors become more pronounced after refrigerating for a day. Those leftover turkey sandwiches for Friday... they'll be amazing.<\/p>

You can't cook this in an oven, so you'll need either a charcoal grill or a smoker to do this. Also, I absolutely insist on using an instant-read meat thermometer. I don't like the leave-it-in style, and temperature is the only way to know when meat is safe to eat. (That is, unless you cook it for 20 hours at 200F like we do the brisket, but that's another story)<\/p>"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"0dd6b8e","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"14d59b9","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100},"elements":[{"id":"245f027","elType":"widget","settings":{"wprm_recipe_id":50},"elements":[],"widgetType":"wprm-recipe"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false}]

item.title: Babi's Kolač
item.dc:creator: ohathawa
item.content:encoded:
This is a recipe our family has been making for a long, long time. Michelle made this a few months after she and Owen met. Babi has been making it since she was a little girl. It's a family tradition.

Like most coffee cakes, this is not too sweet. There's no bitter or savory element here, just yummy goodness.

Oh, and you don't have to use blueberries, but we always do. Maybe once or twice we used raspberries. (Oooh, that sounds goooood!)

Regardless of the berry you use though, this stuff doesn't last long. We sometimes have to make a second one for our guests because we snacked up the first. Oh well. The ingredients are cheap.

Czech Kolač (Blueberry Coffee Cake)

Lightly sweet blueberry cake with streusel on top

Cake

  • 1 tsp baking powder
  • 2 cups all-purpose flour (use Wondra flour for more authenticity)
  • 8 tbsp unsalted butter (room temperature)
  • 1 cup sugar
  • 2 eggs
  • 1 cup buttermilk
  • 2 pints blueberries (use whatever is in season if you can't get blueberries)

Streusel

  • 1 cup flour
  • 1 cup sugar
  • 1/2 cup butter (room temperature)

Coffee Cake

  1. Sift flour and baking powder together in a bowl and set aside

  2. Pre-heat oven to 350°

  3. Cream the butter and sugar using a hand mixer in a small bowl

  4. Mix in the eggs and beat until slightly fluffy

  5. Add buttermilk and mix until smooth

  6. Slowly add the flour and continue mixing until the lumps are mostly gone

  7. Pour batter into a lightly greased cookie sheet

  8. Sprinkle berries evenly on top of the batter

Streusel

  1. In a small bowl, mix the butter, flour and sugar together with a fork

  2. Press the mixture together into the bottom of the bowl and place in the freezer for about 2 minutes

  3. Crumble the streusel evenly on top of the batter

  4. Place the cookie sheet in the oven and bake for about 45 min. or until golden brown on the edges

item.title: Chinese Garlic Sauce for Stir Fry's
item.dc:creator: ohathawa
item.content:encoded:
Chinese Garlic Sauce for Stir Fry

 

This garlic sauce recipe can be used with most any protein. Common dishes in Chinese takeout joints include the snappily named Beef with Garlic Sauce and Chicken in Garlic Sauce. So does that have garlic in it? What type of protein? Can I get the Beef with Garlic Sauce, but substitute the beef with tofu?

Oh. This is from the wonderful Spruce Eats website (I'm not claiming credit for this recipe, just saving it for later reference)

https://www.thespruceeats.com/chinese-garlic-sauce-for-stir-fries-4066674

 

  • 2 tbsp rice vinegar
  • 2 tbsp sugar
  • 1 tbsp light soy sauce (combine light and dark soy sauce measurements if you're using standard grocery store soy sauces)
  • 1 tbsp dark soy sauce
  • 2 tsp Chinese rice wine (substitute dry sherry if needed)
  • 1/2 tsp chili sauce (Sriracha or similar; use enough for your tastes; don't burn out the kids' mouths, but keep it interesting)
  • 1/4 tsp sesame oil
  • 1 1/2 tsp corn starch
  • 1 tbsp water
  • 1 tbsp vegetable oil (or peanut oil)
  • 3 - 4 cloves minced garlic

  1. Combine the rice vinegar, sugar, soy sauces, rice wine or sherry, chili sauce and sesame oil in a small bowl, stirring to combine.

  2. In a separate small bowl, dissolve the cornstarch in water.

  3. Heat 1 tablespoon oil over medium heat in a saucepan. Add the garlic and cook, stirring until aromatic (around 30 seconds).

  4. Quickly re-stir the sauce, add it to the saucepan and bring to a boil, stirring. (This will take about a minute).

  5. Re-stir the cornstarch-water mixture and add it to the sauce, stirring to thicken.

  6. Done - use it in a stir fry recipe

item.title: Crustless Quiche
item.dc:creator: michelle
item.content:encoded:
Crustless Quiche

This is an easy, tasty, health-to-some quiche recipe with no crust

  • 10 oz frozen chopped spinach, drained and squeezed out (about 1 cup)
  • ½ cup grated parmesian cheese
  • ½ cup grated swiss cheese
  • ⅓ cup cooked bacon chopped into 1-inch pieces
  • 2 tbsp cooked garlic
  • 4-5 eggs
  • 1 ½ cups cream (substitute milk, cream, or half and half)

  1. Scatter chopped fillings and cheese into a greased pie pan

  2. In a medium mixing bowl, combine the eggs and cream, beat well

  3. Add eggs and cream to the pie pan

  4. Bake at 425°F for 15 minutes

  5. Lower heat to 350°F

item.title: Amerine Waffles
item.dc:creator: ohathawa
item.content:encoded:
Amerine Waffles

  • 3 eggs
  • 2 cups milk
  • 2 1/4 cups sifted flour
  • 2 tsp baking powder
  • 8 tbsp butter

  1. Warm up the waffle maker (do not grease the irons)

  2. Combine all ingredients in a medium mixing bowl with a hand mixer

  3. Scoop approximately 1/2 cup of batter onto waffle maker and close the lid

  4. Waffles are done in approximately 2 1/2 minutes. They should be golden brown

item.title: Cowboy Beans
item.dc:creator: ohathawa
item.content:encoded:
Ok, we've been making these beans forever. I have totally been in love with BBQ since I was a kid. My mom tells stories of how I'd stuff myself silly on beef ribs when I was 12. Well, I don't have the eating stamina I used to have, but I do have the need to feed on smoky meat. Of course, all good BBQ requires good sides. I'm partial to corn bread, cole slaw, and beans. Problem is, I don't like sweet beans. Most folks add a ton of brown sugar to the beans, and that just ruins a good smoky meal for me. So I went searching for a different way to do pinto beans for my BBQ feasts. I found a recipe at About.com (an old web site that hired "experts" to write posts on topics they knew something about) that served as a great starting point. About.com isn't around anymore, but a version of that original is here at Spruce Eats. This recipe calls for burnt ends, which are fantastic, but I never have them around. So I just use good bacon, scraps if you can get them. The scraps can be cut into delicious little bacon bombs, about 1/2 inch cubed. If you can't get bacon scraps, just use thick slices. Trust me, it's better that way. Oh, and the BBQ sauce you use makes a huge difference. I use our homemade spicy sauce, but use whatever you like.

Cowboy Beans

A BBQ-based pinto bean recipe, nice and hot

  • 2 cups chopped bacon (I like to use scraps if you can find them. You get some bigger chunks that way.)
  • 3 jalapeños sliced
  • 1 large onion chopped
  • 6 cloves garlic minced
  • 1 lb dry pinto beans
  • 8 cups water
  • 1 cup bbq sauce (I use our home recipe)
  • 1 tbsp chili powder
  • 1 tbps worcestershire sauce
  • 1 tsp ground cumin
  • 1 tsp salt

  1. If you aren't using an Instant Pot, soak the beans for 8 hours or so prior to cooking. It's not strictly necessary, but you'll be cooking them forever if you don't.

  2. Sauté bacon in a medium stock pot or the Instant Pot set on Sauté-medium until the fat is translucent

  3. Add the jalapeños and cook for about 3 min.

  4. Add the onions and cook until translucent, about 5 minutes

  5. Add the garlic and cook for 30 seconds to a minute. You want to just start to smell it.

  6. Add the rest of the ingredients.

  7. If you're using an Instant Pot, cook on the default bean setting and do a quick release. If you're using a stock pot, just simmer until you can't stand it anymore, at least 2 hours.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
[{"id":"4de0818","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"eaa039c","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"31d16f2","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

Ok, we've been making these beans forever. I have totally been in love with BBQ since I was a kid. My mom tells stories of how I'd stuff myself silly on beef ribs when I was 12. Well, I don't have the eating stamina I used to have, but I do have the need to feed on smoky meat.

Of course, all good BBQ requires good sides. I'm partial to corn bread, cole slaw, and beans. Problem is, I don't like sweet beans. Most folks add a ton of brown sugar to the beans, and that just ruins a good smoky meal for me. So I went searching for a different way to do pinto beans for my BBQ feasts.

I found a recipe at About.com (an old web site that hired "experts" to write posts on topics they knew something about) that served as a great starting point. About.com isn't around anymore, but a version of that original is here at Spruce Eats.

This recipe calls for burnt ends, which are fantastic, but I never have them around. So I just use good bacon, scraps if you can get them. The scraps can be cut into delicious little bacon bombs, about 1/2 inch cubed. If you can't get bacon scraps, just use thick slices. Trust me, it's better that way.

Oh, and the BBQ sauce you use makes a huge difference. I use our homemade spicy sauce, but use whatever you like.

item.title: Spicy BBQ Sauce
item.dc:creator: ohathawa
item.content:encoded:
We got this recipe from an old Martha Stewart episode. I thought it would be a neat occasional stunt to make our own BBQ sauce. Now this is a staple at our house.

Spicy BBQ Sauce

A smoky, spicy BBQ sauce we got from an old Martha Stewart episode

Dry Ingredients

  • 1/2 cup sugar
  • 1 tbsp celery seed
  • 1 tbps ground cumin
  • 1 tbsp ground red pepper
  • 1 tbsp garlic powder
  • 3/4 tsp chili powder

Wet Ingredients

  • 1 qt ketchup
  • 1 cup apple cider vinegar
  • 3/4 tsp liquid smoke
  • 1/2 tsp lemon juice

  1. Combine all dry ingredients in a small bowl with a fork or small whisk

  2. Combine all wet ingredients in a medium mixing bowl with a hand mixer or a whisk

  3. Gradually add the dry ingredients to the mixing bowl

  4. Mix until combined

  5. Refrigerate overnight for best flavor

item.title: White BBQ
item.dc:creator: ohathawa
item.content:encoded:
I don't know where I grabbed this from. I love it though. Michelle isn't as big a fan, but I love this with BBQ pork. Some day I'll post our BBQ nachos recipe. This is great drizzled on top of that.

White BBQ Sauce

a take on a Southern classic

  • 1 1/2 cups mayonaise
  • 1/4 cup white wine vinegar
  • 1 tbsp coarsely ground black pepper
  • 1 tbsp Creole mustard (you can substitute 1 tsp of dried mustard and 1 tsp of Creole seasoning, like Essence of Emeril)
  • 1 tsp salt
  • 1 tsp sugar
  • 3 cloves garlic minced
  • 2 tsp prepared horseradish

  1. Stick it all in a bowl and mix it up

  2. Refrigerate overnight for best flavor

item.title: Vanishing Oatmeal Raisin Cookies
item.dc:creator: ohathawa
item.content:encoded:
We're adding this recipe because we keep having to transfer the old Quaker Oats lid from generic bin to generic bin. We very rarely buy actual Quaker Oats, but this recipe rocks. Here it is so we don't lose it behind the stove or some such.

Vanishing Oatmeal Raisin Cookies

This is the classic from the bottom of the lid of Quaker Oats. Adding it here just so we don't lose it.

  • 1/2 cup butter (1 stick plus 6 tbsp)
  • 3/4 cup firmly packed brown sugar
  • 1/2 cup granulated sugar
  • 2 eggs
  • 1 tsp vanilla
  • 1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour
  • 1 tsp baking soda
  • 1 tsp cinnamon
  • 1/2 tsp salt (optional)
  • 3 cups uncooked oats
  • 1 cup raisins

  1. Head the oven to 350ºF

  2. In a large bow, beat butter and sugars on medium speed until creamy

  3. Add aggs and vanilla; beat well

  4. Add oats and raisins; mix with a wooden spoon

  5. Drop dough by rounded tablespoonfuls onto ungreased cookie sheets

  6. Bake 8 to 10 minutes or until light brown

item.title: Potatoes Gratin Dauphinois
item.dc:creator: ohathawa
item.content:encoded:
This recipe is one we've used exactly twice a year for the last 30 years. We got it out of one of the greatest cookbooks of all time, one that continues to be relevant even now as it continues to be updated regularly since 1936. Yes, it's Joy of Cooking. I'm not sure which edition we have, but we've had our copy for about 20'ish years. As for the dish. What can I say? It's potatoes au gratin. Creamy, savory, cheesy. Mmmmm. Of course, this thing is so rich and bad for you in several ways that we only make it on Thanksgiving and at Christmas. Every year. For as long as I can remember.

Potatoes Gratin Dauphinois

A classic potatoes au gratin for every holiday

  • 1 clove garlic
  • 1 tbsp butter, softened
  • 2 1/2 lbs potatoes, peeled and very thinly sliced
  • 3 cups milk or half-and-half (these can be combined in any proportion)
  • 1 tsp salt (don't leave this out)
  • 1/4 tsp black pepper
  • 1 pinch nutmeg
  • 1 cup grated Gruyère or Fontinella cheese

  1. Preheat the oven to 350º

  2. Rub a 12-inch gratin dish or shallow 3 qt baking dish with the garlic, then the butter

  3. Add the rest of the ingredients except the cheese to a large sauce pan or Dutch oven

  4. Bring to a gentle boil over medium heat

  5. Cook until slightly thickened, about 5 minutes

  6. Pour the mixture into the baking dish and press the top layer of potatoes down to submerge them

  7. Sprinkle the cheese on top

  8. Bake for 45 minutes to 1 hour
